awd_titl_txt: RTML: Small: Real-Time Model-Based Bayesian Reinforcement Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The applicability of many machine-learning techniques is limited to very specific, fixed application environments.  As opposed to this, model-based Bayesian reinforcement learning technique is a more sophisticated framework, enabling human-like decision-making with evolving objectives and without complete knowledge of the environment. However, its computational complexity is very high, and consequently, its progress has been limited to small-scale demonstrations on limited applications. The goal of this project is to overcome this hurdle by developing innovative algorithm-hardware co-design techniques. The research outcome is expected to greatly accelerate the computation of model-based Bayesian reinforcement learning for practical, large-scale real-life applications, especially those with real-time constraints. The research results will benefit many fields that directly impact society, e.g., driver-less cars, unmanned aerial vehicles, smart agricultural irrigation, robotics for disaster relief and robotic assistants for handicapped people. The research will also train students, including women and other underrepresented groups, for the much needed U.S. workforce in related areas of technology.

The computational kernel of model-based Bayesian reinforcement learning is random sampling over a decision tree. In this project, the computational acceleration will be realized by making use of the intrinsic parallelism offered by the sampling process. Both the memory and the arithmetic bottlenecks of traditional approaches will be addressed. First, a logic circuit based technique will be developed to represent probabilities, and thereby greatly reduce the memory utilization of the algorithm. Second, powerful new arithmetic techniques will be explored to achieve area-efficient computations for the newly proposed number representation. Third, a new sampling method, that is friendly to circuit implementation, will be investigated. Fourth, an approximation technique will be studied to alleviate the complexity arising from tracing sampling histories. Finally, path-aware parallel sampling will be exploited to avoid the redundant computations in software implementations. These techniques and their overall effectiveness will be validated via experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

RTML: Small: Real-Time Model-Based Bayesian Reinforcement Learning

 Jiang Hu and Sunil P. Khatri

Texas A&M University

 

Most reinforcement learning techniques have limited applicability, and are suitable for very niche, fixed application environments. In contrast, this proposal focused on model-based Bayesian reinforcement learning (MBBRL) which is more sophisticated, with human-like decision-making that evolves with time. 

This proposal addressed a key difficulty of MBBRL -- it's computational complexity. The goal of our proposal was to leverage multiple vectors to alleviate the comlexity -- including hardware acceleration, efficient approximate computational approaches, and algorithm-hardware co-design approaches. Computational acceleration was realized by making use of multiple techniques. Powerful new arithmetic techniques were explored to achieve area-efficient computations for the newly proposed neural network architecture with shared layers in state-of-the-art reinforcement learning approach. Additionally approximate scaled population (SP) arithmetic techniques for addition, subtraction, multiplication and division were created and integrated into the overall framework. These approaches were validated through simulated FPGA based prototyping. 

Multiple papers were published along these lines, and at least 3 students were trained in the process. The resulting techniques and research products can be applied to many fields that directly affect human lives, e.g., driverless cars, unmanned aerial vehicles, smart agricultural irrigation, robotics for disaster relief and robotic assistants for handicapped people.

Published results from this work:

1) H. Zhou, S. P. Khatri, J. Hu and F. Liu, “Scaled Population Arithmetic for Efficient Stochastic Computing,” ACM/IEEE Asia and South-Pacific Design Automation Conference (ASP-DAC), 2020.  

2) K. Bharathi, J. Hu and S. P. Khatri, “Scaled Population Subtraction for Stochastic Computation,” IEEE International Conference on Computer Design (ICCD), 2020. 

3) C. Hu, J. Hu and S. P. Khatri, "TD3lite: FPGA Acceleration of Reinforcement Learning with Structural and Representation Optimizations," 33rd International Conference on Field-Programmable Logic and Applications (FPL), 2022.

4) K. Bharathi, S. P. Khatri, and J. Hu, “Scaled Population Division for Approximate Computing,” IEEE International Symposium on Low-Power Electronic Design (ISPLED), 2023.
